options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
n/a
Only live virtual lectures with breakout groups
some recorded lectures on special days (e.g. week of remote classes following thanksgiving break)
Online learning modules

I took notes during lectures and read the sections covered in the textbook while working on the problem sets. The problems on the problem sets were the most helpful in helping me learn. Taking the concepts I learned in class and putting them into use was what made me really understand the material.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much math in just one semester. The pacing was fast compared to high school, but I'm so grateful to Brett for always letting us ask many questions.
I learned how to integrate, apply trig functions, evaluate series and determine convergence/divergence, analyze parametric curves and use polar coordinates.
I learned some new methods and ideas in calculus I'd never been introduced to prior, as well as reviewing some old calculus material.
I better understood calculus. Even though I already knew how to do many of the topics in the class, I got a better understanding this time because it was conceptual and in depth.
I learned a variety of integral techniques as well as other calculus topics.
Calculus ability + critical thinking.
Calc 2, series, solids of revolutions, parametric, polar.
Better knowledge of integration, discrete mathematics (sequences and series), and an introduction to parametric and polar equations/graphing
I gained a deeper appreciation for thinking outside of the box as well as the importance of thinking before doing.
Great critical thinking skills
I developed a strong foundation in Calculus and learned to enjoy math again.

I learned how to integrate a whole bunch of integrals, how to determine if a series converges or diverges, how to calculate volumes using integrals, and other mathematical concepts. More importantly, I learned how to use logic and reasoning to show how I integrated and integral or how I determined if a series converged or diverged. I also learned how and why these concepts exist in mathematics.
I strengthened my understanding of calculus and its concepts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: review sessions for students, great instructor
Weaknesses: n/a
strengths --------------> IF YOU WANT TO DO WELL, GET BRETT SMITH AS A PROFESSOR (he is the best in the department)

This course did an excellent job of explaining some topics, but a lot of the time, I found myself more confused and lost after lecture than before lecture. A lot of the material should have been review for me, but I often found myself less confident on the material the second time through here in 115. Personally, I think the problem lies in the course's tendency to want to spend more time "proving" its concepts and thinking of them in strange, out-of-context manners rather than teaching us the calculus itself. Ultimately, I would urge the instructors to better focus the lectures on the material at hand rather than trying to make wacky polls and puzzles out of said material.

I felt grading on the tests was often very strange. Multiple times, I'd get points off for notation "errors" that were trivial at best, or incorrect at worst: once, I made a disclaimer that I'd be writing a variable a certain different way to help keep my work organized, and then I got points off anyway even though the math was all correct (my pleas for an explanation on Gradescope did not clarify the issue).

The strengths: the course is organized to give students as much help as possible, and peer tutors are super helpful for explaining concepts that were hard to understand in class. 
The weaknesses: this course moved quickly, and after the Thanksgiving/moving back home break, it was difficult to adapt to the schedule right before finals.

Strengths: Homework system--the work before class and the weekly concept checks were very helpful, and the Wednesday due date for PSETs was different from my other PSET-based classes, which was a nice bonus. The Canvas webpage is organized well.

Weaknesses: While the course was structured well on the whole, there would be times when we wouldn't finish a lecture and would never return to the subject. Other times, some areas of study were not dealt with enough.
One of the strengths of this course is its structure, the class is well organized chronologically. A weakness is its breadth of information covered in one semester.

Strengths - 
Well refined course design
Works well with a virtual format

Weaknesses - 
Differences between different professors (some are great and some are not so great)

The course was very well-structured and flowed logically, and it never felt like we were rushing. The explorations were helpful, but sometimes they felt like chores rather than learning opportunities.
More examples

Strengths: so well organized, online learning modules on canvas are very helpful and coherent, lots of supports if need extra help, good use of class time in balancing lecture and discussion/practice problems 

Weaknesses: I was with same few students for my breakout room group for most of the semester, office hours dominated by certain people and was hard to get a question answered. Also, PSET graders did not give helpful feedback whatsoever and it was hard at times to figure out what I did wrong without bothering the professor.

The lectures were fairly engaging and the questions that were in the lectures helped me learn how to apply the concepts that were presented in the lectures. I think that the lectures could be a bit more fast-paced.
My strengths were working on problems I had experience with. My weakness was learning new concepts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the online lectures went so well. And I love how the notes are posted up for students who can't make it or need a refresher
notes being done on electronic tablet of sort, breakout rooms, office hours were good but jamboard is annoying.

The lectures themselves were well done technologically. I never felt like Zoom was an issue. I wish that the lectures were recorded, though, as being able to go back and watch things through a second time would be great, as Zoom classes definitely don't allow the material to stick as well the first time.

Reliance on breakout rooms was a great idea in concept, but I always got put in the same room with two students who refused to talk or turn their cameras on, so I often just found myself working alone.
The frequent office hours were very helpful.

The exams were proctored over Zoom, which was a strange setup. Having to keep your computer tilted down at your paper while you looked at the questions on the same screen was not super enjoyable, and having to keep your mic on but volume down meant that occasionally it felt like you had to check the questions many times. I know some of the other courses did timed psets for exams, and this course may have benefitted from that sort of re-imagining.
Jamboards + Breakout rooms were good.
I think uploading the live lectures would have eased the course somewhat. But overall it wasnt a big issue.

The virtual lectures were somewhat engaging, and the breakout rooms definitely helped, though it is not an ideal method of learning. The tests via zoom actually worked out rather well, and the grade scope problem sets worked out.
For the resources available, the course practices applied during this semester worked very well. I do not have any particular recommendations expect to make the feedback on the exams more explicit.

Although most of the breakout rooms were productive, some were definitely awkward and silent, with people working independently. I do think that the use of Google's Jamboards was effective in having everyone participate on one platform.
Explorations succeeded

Strength: canvas modules, preset Desmos graphs with sliders, balance of class structure to maintain attention, mid class group practice problems, jam board for group sharing

Weakness: because most of the class was freshman, I think many of them werent used to the different platforms let alone using them in a pandemic. I think a more comprehensive overview with suggestions at the beginning of the semester would be helpful  and I realize some things were also said many times. Just going over things like: jam board link is the same add it to bookmarks, the notes are posted after class if you miss something, the lectures are here on canvas.
More of the lectures could be recorded so students can be more flexible especially after we went home.

I think that video shouldn't be required, but it should be highly encouraged. By the end of the semester, everyone had their cameras off and I was the only person with mine on. Eventually, I caved and I turned off my camera in class. After I started having my camera off, I found myself coming into class less prepared. As it was my first class in the morning on Mondays and Wednesdays, I would sometimes start the class in bed until I would have to turn my camera on to answer questions. Looking at a bunch of blank screens with names on them ruined my productivity and engagement during class. I know that I could have had my camera on, but it was so depressing being the only person with it on.
I think that the online course option was a success especially considering certain circumstances. Although it was not the best for my learning style, it was helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Math 115 is a great introduction course, and the great instructors are helping reinforce my love for STEM
Yes

If you need a Calculus credit and feel like 120 is too difficult or 112 is too easy, maybe go for it, but I was not pleased with my experience in this class. Feedback was confusing, lectures often made material more complicated than it should've been, and midterms were taken late at night, leading to a miserable testing experience.
yes, this class is a basic course and is useful
Unless another student needed to take this course for their major, I would not recommend this course to them.
No
I would recommend this course to another student because I think my overall critical thinking veritably improved and I learned a lot of calculus.
Yes definitely, because math is a very valuable skill for any type of stem major this class is a necessity.
Sure. With the right teacher, it is a great option for your first introduction to maths at Yale.

I would! Although I am not planning on going into a math or STEM-related major/field, Calc 2 was definitely an interesting experience that helped me gain conceptual understanding. So, while I may not use information I learned about polar coordinates in the future, I learned a lot of skills that generally helped me with problem solving, which I will undoubtedly need in the future.
Yes! Great instructors

Yes. Great way to learn or sure up Calculus before taking on other classes that require those skills. Good bang for your buck in terms of time commitment and workload for what you learn and the helpfulness of it.
I would recommend it as I found the concepts to be fun and interesting to learn about.
Yes, the class helped strengthen my calculus skills.
